questions.text: Which of the following viruses is brick-shaped?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Poxvirus is brick-shaped as shown below.
  • Poxviruses are large, brick-shaped or oval viruses with a complex structure with a lipid envelope and a linear, covalently closed double-stranded DNA genome.
  • These viruses encode around 100 proteins, including enzymes like DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, enabling them to replicate entirely within the cytoplasm. Some poxviruses, such as those causing smallpox, vaccinia, and molluscum contagiosum, infect humans directly, while others like cowpox and monkeypox primarily affect animals but can also infect humans.

Astrovirus

Ebola Virus

Rhabdo virus

Rota virus

Explanation of other options:

Orthomyxovirus (Option A): Orthomyxoviruses are medium-sized enveloped viruses, and have helical symmetry. Their shape can be spherical or filamentous, with surface spikes that possess either hemagglutinin or neuraminidase functions.

Filovirus(Option C): Filoviruses are pleomorphic, appearing either as elongated filament-like structures or irregular shapes..

Rhabdovirus (Option D): These viruses have a rod-like or bullet-shaped form and each virus particle is encased in a membrane envelope featuring 10 nm-long surface spikes known as peplomers, which are trimers of the virus's glycoprotein.

questions.text: What is the correct sequence in the viral replication cycle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The correct sequence in the viral replication is attachment- penetration- uncoating - synthesis - release.
  • Viral replication generally follows a shared sequence of steps despite variations among virus types.
  • It begins with attachment, where the virus binds to specific receptors on the host cell surface.
  • This is followed by penetration, during which the virus enters the cell through mechanisms like endocytosis or membrane fusion.
  • Next is uncoating, where the viral genome is released from the capsid to become functionally accessible.
  • Once uncoated, the virus enters the expression and synthesis phase, where the viral genome directs the production of mRNA and proteins. These proteins include structural components and enzymes necessary for replication.
  • DNA viruses often use host nuclear enzymes, while RNA viruses may carry their own polymerases, especially in the case of negative-strand RNA viruses.
  • Some viruses also produce microRNAs and regulate gene expression via splicing or polyprotein processing.
  • The next stage, morphogenesis and release, involves assembly of new viral particles. Nonenveloped viruses typically accumulate inside the host cell until lysis, while enveloped viruses acquire their lipid envelope by budding through host membranes. This process is essential for their infectivity.
  • Lastly, maturation may occur, which can be inefficient, with excess viral components sometimes forming inclusion bodies.
  • Viral replication often leads to cell damage or death. Some viruses manipulate apoptosis: delaying it early to boost replication and triggering it later to aid in the spread of progeny virions.

questions.text: Which of the following contains abnormal infectious protein molecules without nucleic acid?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Prions contain abnormal infectious protein molecules without nucleic acid.
  • Prions are infectious agents composed solely of protein, identified in studies of scrapie, a degenerative nervous system disorder in sheep.
  • These agents lack nucleic acids, setting them apart from viruses and viroids, and the term “prion” reflects their protein-based and infectious nature. (Options A and B ruled out)
  • The prion protein (PrP), found in normal individuals as PrPc, undergoes a conformational change to the pathogenic form PrPsc, which contains more β-sheet structures and forms amyloid aggregates.
  • Human prion diseases include Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), kuru, fatal familial insomnia, and Gerstmann-Sträussler-Scheinker disease, while bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) affects cattle.
  • Variant CJD (vCJD) is linked to consumption of infected beef.
  • All prion diseases share the feature of a host-derived glycoprotein converting into a resistant form, and they can be inherited, acquired, or sporadic.
  • A newly identified α-synuclein prion has been implicated in multiple system atrophy.

Explanation of other options:

Viruses (Options A): Viral particles are typically very small in size and are composed of a nucleic acid core, either DNA or RNA, which is enclosed within a protective protein shell known as a capsid. This capsid may be further encased by an envelope made up of lipids, proteins, and carbohydrates. The proteins, often glycoproteins, that form part of the capsid or envelope (such as HIV gp120) are key to determining how a virus interacts with its host. The capsid serves to safeguard the viral nucleic acid.

Viroid (Option B): Certain infectious plant diseases are attributed to viroids, which are small, single-stranded RNA molecules that form covalently closed circular structures with extensive internal base pairing, giving them a rod-like shape. In their extracellular form, viroids consist solely of RNA without any capsid. These RNA molecules do not encode proteins and rely entirely on the host cell's machinery for replication.

Bacteriophage (Option D): Bacteriophages are viruses that infect prokaryotic cells and when it integrates its DNA into a bacterial genome or plasmid, it is termed a prophage.Their nucleic acids which encased in a protein shell can vary and may consist of dsDNA, dsRNA, ssRNA, or ssDNA, sometimes containing modified bases like hydroxymethylcytosine. Many phages possess tail structures that help them attach to bacterial receptors and inject their genetic material into host cells.

questions.text: An investigator studying viral replication isolates the genetic material of an unidentified virus strain. After exposing a cell culture to the isolated, purified viral genetic material, the cells begin to replicate the viral genome directly. Infection with the investigated strain is most likely to cause which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the given options, poliovirus which causes polio has +sense ssRNA  which can readily be translated into the viral genome directly.

  • RNA viruses replicate and produce mRNA primarily in the cytoplasm, and their genomes are classified based on their polarity: positive-sense, negative-sense, or ambisense.
  • Positive-sense RNA viruses, such as picornaviruses, flaviviruses, and coronaviruses, have genomes that act directly as mRNA.
  • These genomes are inherently infectious, immediately bind to ribosomes, and begin translation without the need for prior transcription.
  • They encode viral proteins either as a single polyprotein that is cleaved or as several mRNAs derived from a full-length template.
  • In contrast, negative-sense RNA viruses, like rhabdoviruses and paramyxoviruses, cannot serve directly as mRNA.
  • Their genomes must be transcribed by a virus-encoded RNA-dependent RNA polymerase into positive-sense mRNA before translation.
  • These polymerases are packaged within the virion since host cells lack the machinery to replicate or transcribe RNA.
  • Negative-sense RNA viruses generate full-length positive-sense templates to replicate their genomes and produce individual mRNAs for protein synthesis.
  • Some viruses like reoviruses possess segmented, double-stranded RNA genomes, requiring complex transcription strategies.
  • Arenaviruses exhibit an ambisense pattern with both negative and positive segments, while retroviruses carry positive-sense RNA but replicate via a reverse transcription mechanism.
  • The genetic material of DNA viruses can be single or double stranded, linear or circular. Like the viruses with positive sense RNA, DNA viruses are also inherently infectious.
  • DNA viruses generally utilize the host cell’s nuclear machinery for transcription and replication. Most DNA viruses undergo transcription in the nucleus with the help of host DNA-dependent RNA polymerase II to produce viral mRNAs.

Explanation of other options:

Measles (Option A): Measles belongs to the family paramyxoviridae which possess negative sense RNA.

Hepatitis B (Option B): Hepatitis B virus belongs to the family hepadnaviridae which replicate uniquely by first generating a longer-than-genome positive-strand RNA, which is reverse transcribed into DNA by a viral enzyme, resulting in a partially double-stranded circular DNA genome.

Rabies (Option C): Rabies virus belongs to the family rhabdoviridae which contains negative sense RNA.

questions.text:
Which of the following viruses have segmented RNA?
1. Coronavirus
2. Bunyavirus
3. Arenavirus
4. Filovirus
5. Rhabdovirus
6. Calicivirus
7. Orthomyxovirus
8. Picornavirus
9. Reovirus
10.Togavirus
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Among the given options, Bunyavirus, Arenavirus, Orthomyxovirus, and Reovirus have segmented RNA which makes option A the correct answer. 
  • Coronaviruses possess an unsegmented, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA genome enclosed within an enveloped particle and replicates in the cytoplasm.
  • Bunyaviruses are enveloped viruses with a triple-segmented, single-stranded RNA genome that is either negative-sense or ambisense. Genome replication takes place in the cytoplasm, and the virus acquires its envelope by budding through the Golgi apparatus.
  • Arenaviruses are pleomorphic, enveloped viruses with a segmented, circular, single-stranded RNA genome that is both negative-sense and ambisense. Replication occurs in the cytoplasm, and host ribosomes are incorporated during maturation, giving the virions a characteristic sandy appearance.
  • Filoviruses are enveloped, pleomorphic viruses that appear long and threadlike with a linear, negative-sense, single-stranded RNA genome of 18–19 kb, and include pathogens like Marburg and Ebola viruses.
  • Rhabdoviruses are enveloped viruses shaped like bullets and contain a linear, nonsegmented, single-stranded negative-sense RNA genome ranging from 11 to 15 kb, and assemble by budding from the cell membrane.
  • Caliciviruses are non-enveloped viruses with cup-shaped surface depressions and contain a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA genome, They resemble picornaviruses and include noroviruses, which are important causes of epidemic acute gastroenteritis.
  • Orthomyxoviruses are enveloped, helical viruses and may appear round or filamentous, with projections containing hemagglutinin or neuraminidase. Their genome consists of segmented, linear, negative-sense, single-stranded RNA.
  • Picornaviruses are small, ether-resistant viruses with cubic symmetry, containing a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA genome.
  • Reoviruses are nonenveloped viruses with icosahedral symmetry, and possess a segmented, double-stranded RNA genome consisting of 10 to 12 segments.
  • Togaviruses are enveloped viruses with a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA genome and the virions mature by budding from host cell membranes.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses has an envelope composed of nuclear membrane molecules?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Herpes virus to which varicella zoster virus belongs derives its envelope from the host nuclear membrane.
  • The viral envelope is a lipid-containing membrane acquired during maturation through budding from a host cell membrane.
  • Viral glycoproteins are displayed on its surface, forming structures known as peplomers.

Some of the non-enveloped viruses are given in the table below.

  • Herpesviruses are large, enveloped viruses containing a double-stranded DNA genome that is linear and often displays terminal and internal repeat sequences. The herpes virus which frequently infects humans are numbered 1 to 8.
  • The nucleocapsid exhibits icosahedral symmetry with 162 capsomeres, and the envelope, derived from the nuclear membrane of infected cells, contains viral glycoprotein spikes and surrounds an intermediate tegument layer.
  • Varicella-zoster virus which is human herpes virus-3 causes two distinct illnesses: varicella (chickenpox), a highly contagious condition in children marked by widespread vesicular eruptions, and herpes zoster (shingles), a painful rash confined to a single dermatome as shown below, seen mainly in older or immunocompromised individuals.
  • While varicella results from primary infection, herpes zoster occurs due to reactivation of latent virus residing in sensory ganglia.

Explanation of other options:

Adenovirus (Option A): Adenovirus contains DNA as their genetic material and are non-enveloped viruses.

Poliovirus (Option C): Poliovirus belongs to the family picornavirus which are non-enveloped RNA viruses.

Rotavirus (Option D): Rotavirus belongs to the order reoviridae which are non-enveloped viruses with segmented dsRNA.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to his paediatrician with a high fever. He was feeling fatigued yesterday and then developed a high fever overnight that was accompanied by chills and malaise. This morning he also started complaining of headaches and myalgias. He is given oseltamivir and given instructions to rest and stay hydrated. Which of the following properties is required for the viral genetic change that permits global pandemics of this virus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical features suggest a diagnosis of viral infection with influenza and its segmented genomic material permits the viral genetic change (antigenic shift) that leads to global pandemics.
  • Influenza viruses, belonging to the Orthomyxoviridae family, are major respiratory pathogens known for their high mutation rates and genetic reassortment, contributing to seasonal epidemics and occasional pandemics.
  • These viruses are roughly spherical and possess a lipid envelope derived from the host cell membrane.
  • The viral genome is composed of segmented, single-stranded, negative-sense RNA :eight segments in influenza A and B, and seven in influenza C.
  • These segments encode various proteins, including nine structural proteins such as nucleoprotein (NP), matrix proteins (M1, M2), and the surface glycoproteins hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA).
  • HA facilitates viral attachment to sialic acid receptors and mediates membrane fusion, while NA plays a role in viral release and prevents virion aggregation by removing sialic acids.
  • Antigenic variations in HA and NA give rise to antigenic drift (minor point mutations) and antigenic shift (major reassortments between segments of two different viruses of the same type), the latter often resulting in pandemics. (Options A, B, and C ruled out)
  • Clinical infection primarily involves the upper respiratory tract and is marked by fever, malaise, myalgia, and cough. Complications include pneumonia, especially in vulnerable populations, and rare conditions like Reye syndrome in children using aspirin.
  • Diagnosis is made via RT-PCR, viral culture, serology, or antigen detection. Immunity is strain-specific, and antigenic drift enables reinfection.

questions.text: When hepatitis D was injected into an immunocompromised mouse, there was no detectable hepatitis D RNA in the blood at any time point during the next several months. When co-injected with hepatitis B, hepatitis D RNA was detected in the blood. Which of the following best describes this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The phenomenon wherein Hepatitis D virus requires the help of Hepatitis D virus to infect a cell is called complementation.
  • Hepatitis D virus (HDV), also known as the delta agent, is a defective virus that cannot replicate or infect cells independently.
  • It requires coinfection with hepatitis B virus (HBV) because HDV lacks the genes necessary for producing its own envelope proteins.
  • HBV provides the hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), which is essential for HDV to form its envelope and infect host cells.
  • This interaction exemplifies complementation (a type of viral interaction), where one virus supplies a missing gene product to support the replication of a defective virus without altering either virus’s genotype.
  • As a result, HDV can only propagate in individuals already infected with HBV, using the envelope proteins made by HBV for entry and spread.
  • Acute hepatitis D infection can occur either through coinfection with hepatitis B virus (HBV) at the same time or as a superinfection in someone who already has chronic HBV infection.
  • In cases of coinfection, antibodies against the hepatitis D antigen (HDAg) tend to appear later during the acute phase and are often present in low levels. For more reliable detection, it is better to test for HDAg or HDV RNA in the blood, or look for IgM antibodies specific to HDV.
  • During recovery from coinfection, these markers including HDV RNA and even anti-HDV antibodies typically disappear within months or years.
  • In contrast, superinfection with HDV leads to chronic HDV infection in over 70% of cases, with sustained high levels of both IgM and IgG antibodies against HDV, as well as continued detection of HDV RNA and HDAg.
  • Superinfections are more likely to cause severe liver damage, including fulminant hepatitis.
  • Other types of viral interactions include recombination, phenotypic mixing, and interference.

Explanation of other options:

Recombination (Option B): Recombination is a process where viral progeny acquire genetic traits not simultaneously present in either parent virus. It typically involves breaking of nucleic acid strands and fusing portions of genomes from two parental viruses, producing a recombinant virus that is genetically stable and replicates consistently.

Interference (Option C): Interference refers to the inhibition of replication of one virus when two viruses infect the same cell or host simultaneously. This phenomenon is independent of specific immunity and does not occur with all virus combinations. Interference can happen through various mechanisms. One virus may block or destroy the cellular receptors needed by the other virus, as seen with retroviruses or orthomyxoviruses. Another mechanism is that the two viruses might compete for replication machinery like polymerases or initiation factors, or the first virus may stimulate the cell to produce inhibitory substances such as interferons that block the replication of the second virus.

Viral vector (Option D):  Recombinant DNA technology has enabled viral genomes to be used as tools for expressing both viral and cellular genes, making it possible to produce biological substances like hormones, vaccines, and interferons. This technology utilizes both DNA viruses and RNA viruses each offering unique benefits and limitations.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses would not be disrupted if treated with a detergent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Among the given options, picornavirus would not be disrupted if treated with a detergent since non-enveloped viruses are resistant to detergents.
  • Some of the non-enveloped viruses are given in the table below.
  • A viral envelope is a lipid-rich membrane that surrounds certain virus particles and is acquired during maturation through a budding process involving cellular membranes.
  • This budding typically takes place at the plasma membrane but can also occur at other intracellular membranes.
  • For instance, herpesviruses acquire their envelopes from the nuclear membrane of the host cell, and the lipid makeup of the viral envelope reflects the composition of that specific membrane.
  • The envelope contains virus-encoded glycoproteins, which are displayed on its surface as projections called peplomers.
  • These glycoproteins are inserted into the host membrane before budding, allowing the viral nucleocapsid to incorporate them during envelopment.
  • Notably, enveloped viruses are non-infectious until the envelope is acquired, and infectious virions generally do not build up within the infected cell.
  • The structure and lipid content of the envelope are crucial for infectivity, as disruption of the lipid membrane such as by ether or detergents renders the virus non-infectious.
  • Hence, lipid-containing viruses are sensitive to these agents, while non-enveloped (nonlipid-containing) viruses are typically resistant.
  • Explanation of other options:
  • Herpesvirus (Option A): Herpesviruses are large viruses featuring a nucleocapsid with cubic symmetry and 162 capsomeres. They possess a lipid-containing envelope and a linear, double-stranded DNA genome.
  • Hepadnavirus (Option B): Hepadnaviruses are small, enveloped viruses and contain circular, partially double-stranded DNA. They have an icosahedral nucleocapsid core surrounded by the lipid-containing envelope with viral surface antigen.
  • Flavivirus (Option C): Flaviviruses are enveloped viruses and possess a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA genome. Their mature virions accumulate within the cisternae of the endoplasmic reticulum.

questions.text: Inclusion bodies are aggregates of viral proteins or virions that confer altered staining properties to host cells. You find the following inclusion body in a particular cell and are asked whether the given inclusions are intracytoplasmic, intranuclear, or both. Which of the following cases will show inclusion bodies at a similar site to the one you identified above?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows the owl eye inclusions (nuclear) seen in cytomegalovirus infected cells which also have intracytoplasmic inclusions ,and inclusions in the same sites can also be seen in a 7-year-old with coryza and Koplik's spots which describe measles.
  • Cells infected by cytomegalovirus become notably enlarged and display variation in cell and nuclear shape.
  • They characteristically contain prominent intranuclear basophilic inclusions that occupy nearly half of the nucleus and are typically separated from the nuclear membrane by a distinct clear zone giving the characteristic owl eye
  • Additionally, smaller basophilic inclusions may also be observed in the cytoplasm of these infected cells.
  • During viral replication inside host cells, distinct virus-induced structures known as inclusion bodies may form.
  • These inclusions, often larger than individual virions and stainable with acidic dyes like eosin, can be located in the nucleus, the cytoplasm, or both locations in the case of certain viruses like measles.
  • These structures often function as sites for viral assembly and development. The appearance of inclusion bodies varies depending on the fixative and staining methods used during tissue processing.
  • Measles virus infected lymphoid tissues show follicular hyperplasia and large germinal centers, along with scattered multinucleated giant cells called Warthin-Finkeldey cells as shown below, which contain eosinophilic inclusions in both the nucleus and cytoplasm.These cells are diagnostic of measles and may also appear in the lungs and sputum.

Other named inclusion bodies are summarised in the table given below.

Explanation of other options:

A 12-year-old with a dog bite experiencing hydrophobia (Option A): This is suggestive of rabies which causes formation of intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies known as negri bodies.

A patient with travel history to Africa presenting with fever and jaundice (Option B): This history points to a diagnosis of yellow fever which forms Cowdry A bodies which are intranuclear.

A 5-year-old with raised umbilicated papules in the genital area (Option D): This describes lesions of molluscum contagiosum which forms intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies known as Henderson-Patterson bodies.

questions.text: An abnormal replication cycle in influenza virus with high hemagglutinin titer but low infectivity in the virus. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Abnormal replication cycle in an influenza virus with high hemagglutinin titer but low infectivity occurs due to Von Magnus phenomenon.
  • During abnormal viral replication cycles, some progeny virions may be non-infectious due to faulty assembly. This phenomenon is observed when cells are infected with high doses of certain viruses, such as influenza, resulting in high hemagglutinin titers but low infectivity. This scenario is termed the von Magnus phenomenon.
  • In some cells, viral infection does not yield infectious particles due to a cellular block in replication and this is called an abortive infection, where the failure lies in the cell type rather than in the virus. (Option C ruled out)
  • Additionally, some viruses are genetically defective, meaning they cannot independently produce complete progeny. Their replication depends on the simultaneous presence of a helper virus that can supply the missing genetic functions.
  • For example, certain strains of Rous sarcoma virus (RSV) lack genes for the viral envelope and require a helper virus such as avian leukosis virus to form infectious progeny. The envelope proteins of such progeny are determined by the helper virus. Other examples include hepatitis D virus, which relies on hepatitis B, and adeno-associated satellite viruses, which depend on adenoviruses.
  • These genetically deficient viruses that require helper activity to produce infectious particles are termed defective viruses. (Option D ruled out)
  • Pseudovirions are a unique kind of defective viral particle that package host cell DNA instead of the virus’s own genetic material. During replication, the viral capsid may mistakenly encapsulate fragments of host nucleic acid rather than viral nucleic acid. Although these structures resemble typical virus particles under electron microscopy, they are incapable of replication. However, they may have the potential to transfer host cell genetic material between cells. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: Choose the correct statement with respect to nucleic acid replication in viruses
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • All DNA viruses replicate in the nucleus except Poxvirus which replicates in the cytoplasm.
  • DNA virus genomes are replicated in the nucleus using host enzymes, except for poxviruses which operate in the cytoplasm. (Option A ruled out)
  • The complexity of DNA viruses influences how they regulate viral gene expression. Transcription may proceed from either DNA strand and include intron splicing, such as in papillomaviruses and adenoviruses. DNA replication uses DNA-dependent DNA polymerase and requires a primer, with replication being semiconservative.
  • Simple DNA viruses like parvovirus depend on host enzymes, while complex viruses encode their own. Parvovirus uses self-hybridizing inverted DNA sequences as a primer, adenovirus uses a deoxycytidine-protein primer, and herpesvirus has its own primase.
  • Large DNA viruses like herpesvirus and adenovirus encode their own enzymes to replicate in growing and non-growing cells. Smaller ones like parvovirus rely on actively dividing cells due to limited internal enzymatic machinery. For example, parvoviruses infect erythroid precursors.
  • Viral polymerases are faster but more error-prone than host enzymes, making them targets for antiviral drugs.
  • Hepadnaviruses are unique: they synthesize a positive-strand RNA copy of their DNA genome using host RNA polymerase, then convert it into DNA via reverse transcription. The process halts during positive-strand DNA synthesis, yielding a partially double-stranded DNA genome.
  • Replication in most RNA viruses occurs in the cytoplasm except for orthomyxovirus. In retrovirus, the cDNA is synthesised in the cytoplasm and integrated into the host genome which is then transcribed in the nucleus. (Options C and D ruled out)
  • Positive-sense RNA viruses directly serve as mRNA. These viruses contain a replication complex to organize viral components for efficient genome replication and transcription. Negative-sense RNA viruses use the negative genome to make mRNA via viral polymerase, which must enter the host cell with the genome

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the nucleic acid of the smallest DNA virus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The smallest virus is the parvovirus which is a ss DNA virus.
  • Parvoviruses are the smallest viruses, with an icosahedral, nonenveloped structure. Their genome consists of linear, single-stranded DNA. (Options B, C, and D ruled out)
  • Most of the DNA viruses have double stranded DNA and few examples of DNA viruses with single stranded DNA are parvoviridae and anelloviridae.
  • Most of the RNA viruses have a single copy of unsegmented single stranded genome but retroviridae have two copies of single stranded RNA.
  • Segmented RNA viruses include Bunyaviridae, Orthoviridae, Reoviridae, and Arenaviridae and Reoviridae has double stranded RNA.
  • Human parvovirus B19, belonging to the Erythroparvovirus genus, is pathogenic and exhibits a tropism for erythroid progenitor cells.
  • Viral replication is heavily reliant on host cell functions and occurs in the nucleus. Because parvoviruses cannot initiate DNA synthesis, they must infect dividing cells.
  • They lack the ability to stimulate resting cells and therefore depend on the host’s DNA polymerases.
  • For parvovirus B19, replication takes place primarily in erythroid progenitor cells expressing blood group P antigen (globoside), with α5β1 integrin serving as a coreceptor.
  • The viruses are environmentally stable and can persist in the blood and respiratory secretions, with transmission primarily via the respiratory route.
  • Clinically, parvovirus B19 is associated with a variety of conditions: erythema infectiosum (fifth disease) in children and occasionally adults, presenting as a slapped-cheek facial rash, as shown below, with possible joint symptoms.
  • Transient aplastic crisis can occur in individuals with underlying hemolytic anemias such as sickle cell disease. Other manifestations include chronic anemia and pure red cell aplasia in immunodeficient patients and hydrops fetalis due to fetal anemia following vertical transmission during maternal infection.
  • Persistent infections are noted in immunocompromised patients, with chronic suppression of bone marrow.
  • Diagnosis is primarily via detection of viral DNA through PCR, with B19 DNA detectable in serum, blood cells, respiratory secretions, and tissue. Serological tests for IgM and IgG antibodies are also used, though IgG persists longer post-infection

questions.text: Shedding of viruses is a necessary step to maintain viruses in the environment or host. Which of the following viruses is not shed, thus making humans a dead-end host?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Among the given options, rhabdovirus is not shed into the environment from infected individuals which makes humans a dead-end host in rabies.
  • The process of viral pathogenesis involves a sequence of steps: the virus enters the host, undergoes initial replication, spreads within the body, induces cellular damage, triggers an immune response, and ultimately is either cleared or establishes a persistent infection, culminating in the shedding of the virus.
  • Viral shedding refers to the release of infectious virus particles into the environment, typically from the same body surfaces through which the virus originally entered.
  • The timing and pattern of shedding vary by virus and disease stage. Shedding marks the phase when the infected person can transmit the infection.
  • However, in certain viral diseases like rabies, humans serve as dead-end hosts, so virus shedding does not occur.
  • The mechanism of viral spread in the body in various viral infections is illustrated in the image below.

Explanation of other options:

Poliovirus (Option B): Poliovirus enters through the mouth and initially replicates in the oropharynx or intestinal tract. Although its presence in the throat diminishes after a week, it continues to be shed in feces for several weeks, even when antibody levels in the blood are elevated.

Varicella-zoster (Option C): Varicella is easily transmitted through airborne droplets or direct contact. An individual with varicella is likely contagious starting just before the rash appears and remains so during the initial days of the rash.

Hepatitis B (Option D): Modes of transmission of Hepatitis B virus include vertical, contact, and parenteral.

questions.text: Match the following cytopathic effect on light microscope and their causative virus
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The viruses with their respective cytopathic changes are correctly matched in option B, A-4 B-3 C-1 D-2.
  • When viruses replicate in cell cultures, they often cause visible structural changes in host cells, known as cytopathic effects (CPE).
  • These changes include shrinking, swelling, rounding of cells, and the formation of syncytia or clusters. Such effects help in the presumptive identification of the virus, especially when the clinical presentation is already known.
  • For example, respiratory syncytial virus typically forms multinucleated giant cells, while adenoviruses form grapelike clusters of large round cells.
  • Some viruses, such as rubella, do not cause direct CPE but can be detected through their ability to interfere with the CPE of another virus, a process termed viral interference.

The various cytopathic effects shown by different viruses are summarised in the table below.

questions.text: The following image depicts a schematic diagram of an embryonated egg used for viral cultivation. Which of the following sites will you use to cultivate vaccines for someone travelling to an endemic area for yellow fever?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Allantoic sac is used for 17D vaccine production used to prevent yellow fever.
  • Viruses, being obligate intracellular parasites, cannot be grown on non-living culture media.
  • To cultivate them, three primary methods are used: inoculation into animals, embryonated eggs, or tissue cultures.
  • Embryonated Eggs: First introduced by Goodpasture and refined by Burnet, the embryonated hen’s egg provides multiple sites for virus cultivation:
    • Chorioallantoic membrane (CAM): Used for observing visible lesions or pocks, which vary in appearance depending on the virus. Pock formation helps in quantifying viruses like variola or vaccinia. (Option D ruled out)
    • Allantoic cavity: Offers a high yield for viruses such as influenza and certain paramyxoviruses.
    • Amniotic sac: Primarily used for isolating influenza viruses. (Option B ruled out)
    • Yolk sac: Useful for growing certain viruses, chlamydiae, and rickettsiae. (Option A ruled out)
  • The allantoic route is particularly important for large-scale cultivation of influenza viruses used in vaccines. Other vaccines like yellow fever (17D strain) and rabies (Flury strain) are also made using chick embryonated eggs.
  • Duck eggs, with their larger size and longer incubation period, are sometimes preferred due to better virus yield and have been used in making inactivated rabies vaccines.

questions.text: Cell lines are classified according to the number of cell divisions they can undergo. Which of the following is not an example of a continuous cell line, which is capable of indefinite growth?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Among the given options, monkey kidney cell line is an example of a primary cell line and not a continuous cell line.
  • Viruses, being obligate intracellular parasites, cannot be cultured on non-living media.
  • Their cultivation is accomplished through three main approaches: animal inoculation, embryonated eggs, and tissue culture.
  • Animal Inoculation: Routes of inoculation include intracerebral, subcutaneous, intraperitoneal, and intranasal. Guinea pigs, rabbits, and ferrets may also be used.
  • Virus growth is detected via death, disease, or lesions, although repeated passages may be required.
  • Embryonated Eggs: Embryonated hen’s eggs provide multiple sites for virus growth.
  • Tissue Culture: This became prominent after antibiotics reduced bacterial contamination.

Types of Tissue Cultures:

  • Organ Culture: Maintains small organ segments in vitro, preserving structure and function. Used for viruses that are highly organ-specific, like coronaviruses.
  • Explant Culture: Involves minced tissue embedded in plasma clots or suspension. Once a standard virology technique, it's now rarely used but was important for isolating adenoviruses.
  • Cell Culture: Most commonly used. Tissues are dissociated using enzymes like trypsin. Cells are suspended in growth media, allowed to adhere, and form monolayers. Cultures are grown as ‘stationary’ or in ‘roller drums’.

Cell cultures are categorized into:

  • Primary Cell Culture
    • These are normal cells derived from animal or human cells.
    • Able to grow only for a limited time and cannot be maintained in serial culture.
    • Used for the primary isolation of viruses and production of vaccines.
    • Examples: Monkey kidney cell culture, Human amnion cell culture.
  • Diploid Cell Culture (Semi-continuous cell lines)
    • Cells are diploid and contain the same number of chromosomes as the parent cells.
    • Can be sub-cultured up to 50 times by serial transfer, after which senescence occurs and the strain is lost.
    • Used for the isolation of some fastidious viruses and production of viral vaccines.
    • Examples: Human embryonic lung strain, Rhesus embryo cell strain.
  • Heteroploid Cultures (Continuous cell lines)
    • Derived from cancer cells.
    • Can be serially cultured indefinitely, hence called continuous cell lines.
    • Maintained either by serial subculture or by deep-freezing at –70°C.
    • Due to derivation from cancer cells, not useful for vaccine production.
    • Examples: HeLa (Human carcinoma of cervix cell line), HEP-2 (Human epithelioma of larynx cell line).

Explanations of other options:

HEp-2 cell line (Option B): HEp-2 cell line stands for human epithelioma of larynx cell line which is an example of continuous cell line.

Vero cell line (Option C): Vervet monkey kidney cell line is an example of continuous cell line.

BHK-21 (Option D): Baby hamster kidney cell line is a type of continuous cell line.

questions.text: By which phenomenon does the OPV vaccine prevent an outbreak of wild polio strains?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • OPV vaccine can prevent an outbreak of wild polio strains by the phenomenon of viral interference.
  • Interference refers to the phenomenon where infection of a cell by one virus hampers the concurrent or subsequent infection by another virus.
  • This effect, often mediated by interferon, is distinct from immune responses and does not occur with every virus combination, as some viruses can still replicate efficiently within the same host cell.
  • Interference may arise through various mechanisms. One virus can block or destroy cell receptors, preventing the second virus from attaching. Examples include retroviruses and enteroviruses blocking, and orthomyxoviruses destroying receptors.
  • Another mechanism involves one virus outcompeting the other for replication machinery like polymerases or initiation factors.
  • Additionally, one virus may stimulate the production of substances like interferon in the infected cell, which inhibits the replication of other viruses.
  • Different types of interference have been described. One such form, ‘autointerference,’ occurs when a high viral load inhibits production of infectious progeny.
  • Interference has practical applications, such as the use of live attenuated poliovirus vaccine to block wild poliovirus. However, pre-existing enteric viruses can also interfere with vaccine virus replication, potentially compromising its efficacy.

Examples of other options:

Genetic recombination(Option A):  Recombination leads to the creation of a new progeny virus, known as a recombinant, that possesses characteristics not simultaneously present in either parent virus. This process typically involves the breaking of nucleic acid strands and the joining of genetic segments from two different parent genomes. The resulting recombinant virus is genetically stable and continues to produce similar progeny upon replication.

Complementation (Option B): Complementation describes the interaction between gene products of two viruses co-infecting a cell, where one or both viruses may have genetic defects. This interaction enables replication of one or both viruses in conditions where they normally could not replicate. The process occurs when one virus supplies a functional gene product that compensates for a defect in the other virus, thereby supporting its replication. Importantly, the genetic material of both viruses remains unchanged.

questions.text: All are mosquito borne viral fevers except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Kyasanur forest disease is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever while the others are mosquito borne.
  • Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) is a hemorrhagic fever identified in Karnataka, India, in 1957 following the discovery of dead monkeys in Shimoga district and the onset of febrile illness in local villagers.
  • The virus, related to the Russian spring-summer encephalitis (RSSE) complex, was first isolated by the Virus Research Centre in Pune.
  • While monkeys serve as amplifying hosts due to fatal infection, forest birds and small mammals are considered reservoir hosts.
  • Transmission occurs via the bite of Haemaphysalis spinigera ticks, which may also support transovarial transmission.
  • Clinically, KFD presents abruptly with fever, headache, conjunctivitis, muscle pain, and marked exhaustion.
  • Hemorrhagic manifestations may involve the skin, mucosa, and internal organs.

Explanation of other options:

Japanese encephalitis (Option A): Transmitted by culex mosquitoes.

Yellow fever (Option B): Aedes mosquito is responsible for transmission of yellow fever.

Dengue (Option D): Dengue is spread by Aedes mosquito.
